s.text: On the window above the sink a small container is stuffed with bits of leftovers--the red berries of barberry, small twigs of willow, cuttings of hinoki cypress with its fruits attached, and the pendulous leathery seed pods of wisteria.

On the window above the sink a small container is stuffed with bits of leftovers--the red berries of barberry, small twigs of willow, cuttings of hinoki cypress with its fruits attached, and the pendulous leathery seed pods of wisteria.

On the window above the sink a small container is stuffed with bits of leftovers--the red berries of barberry, small twigs of willow, cuttings of hinoki cypress with its fruits attached, and the pendulous leathery seed pods of wisteria.
I waited for the relief that winter would bring.
I arranged them carefully, watered them dutifully, and checked their progress constantly, recording their growth rates and bloom times.
I arranged them carefully, watered them dutifully, and checked their progress constantly, recording their growth rates and bloom times.
I arranged them carefully, watered them dutifully, and checked their progress constantly, recording their growth rates and bloom times.
I arranged them carefully, watered them dutifully, and checked their progress constantly, recording their growth rates and bloom times.
At the supermarket, I stared for a long time at the delectable dark green foliage and deep red stem and spine of Swiss chard.
I lived to watch the progress of these, my darlings.
Near the house was a badly-coifed flowering quince that had only a handful of lovely flowers for a few days in May and one or two fruits clinging pathetically in late summer.
Jam as many into the dirt as possible, water them, and then secure them in a Ziploc bag before sending them off to the cold, dark place required for dormancy.
